title: How to setup DNS
content:
Setting up DNS (Domain Name System) is crucial for directing web traffic to your website. Follow these steps to configure your DNS settings effectively:

1. Access Your Domain Registrar

Log in to the control panel of your domain registrar where you purchased your domain name.

2. Locate DNS Settings

Find the section for managing DNS or Name Servers. This is usually labeled as DNS Management, DNS Settings, or Name Server Management.

3. Understand DNS Records

Familiarize yourself with the different types of DNS records:

  • A Record: Points your domain to an IP address.
  • CNAME Record: Maps an alias to a true domain name.
  • MX Record: Directs email to the correct mail server.
  • TXT Record: Used for various verification and security purposes.

4. Create or Update Records

To point your domain to a web server, follow these steps:

  1. Create an A Record:
    • Hostname: Use "@" for the root domain or "www" for the subdomain.
    • Value: Enter the IP address of your web server.
  2. If needed, create a CNAME Record for subdomains:
    • Hostname: The subdomain (e.g., "blog").
    • Value: The main domain (e.g., "example.com").
  3. Set up MX Records if you're using email:
    • Priority: Assign a priority value (lower numbers indicate higher priority).
    • Value: Enter the mail server address (e.g., "mail.example.com").

5. Save Changes

After adding or updating the records, make sure to save the changes.

6. Wait for DNS Propagation

DNS changes can take up to 48 hours to propagate worldwide. During this time, your website may not be accessible to everyone.

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can successfully set up DNS for your domain, ensuring that visitors can reach your website by entering your domain name.
